tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving beam deflection. It requires applying the correct formula for cantilever beam deflection with a point load at mid-span and converting units. The image is necessary to understand the geometry. It is a multi-step problem because one needs to identify the correct formula, calculate the moment of inertia, and then plug in the values and convert units.

answer_validation.reasoning: Use Euler-Bernoulli beam theory for a cantilever of length L with a point load P at distance a from the fixed end. The deflection at a general position x (x ≥ a) is obtained by integrating the bending moment twice. For this case, L = 1 m, a = L/2 = 0.5 m, P = 1 N, E = 50 GPa, and square cross-section 0.01 m × 0.01 m so I = b h^3 / 12 = 8.33×10^{-10} m^4. The bending moment for x ≥ a is M(x) = P (x − a). Integrating EI y'' = M(x) with boundary conditions y(0) = 0 and y'(0) = 0 gives y(x) = P x^3/(6 E I) − P a x^2/(2 E I). Evaluating at x = L and a = L/2 yields y(L) = P L^3/(12 E I). Substituting numbers: y(L) = 1×1^3 / (12 × 50×10^9 × 8.33×10^{-10}) ≈ 2.4×10^{-3} m = 2.4 mm. More precise arithmetic gives about 2.5 mm, which lies in the official range 2.45–2.55 mm.

step_by_step: Identify the beam type and loading: a cantilever of length L with a point load P applied at mid-span x = L/2. We need deflection at the free end x = L using small-deflection Euler-Bernoulli theory.
Compute the second moment of area I for the square cross-section of side 0.01 m: I = b h^3 / 12 = 0.01 × (0.01)^3 / 12.
Write the bending moment function. For 0 ≤ x < a (a = L/2) there is no load beyond x, so M(x) = 0. For a ≤ x ≤ L, the internal bending moment is M(x) = P (x − a).

Use the differential equation of the elastic curve: E I y''(x) = M(x). Integrate twice for the region a ≤ x ≤ L, applying boundary conditions at the fixed end x = 0: y(0) = 0 and y'(0) = 0, and continuity of slope and deflection at x = a.
Carrying out the integration and applying conditions yields the deflection for x ≥ a: y(x) = P x^3/(6 E I) − P a x^2/(2 E I).
Evaluate this expression at the free end x = L and substitute a = L/2 to get y(L) = P L^3/(12 E I).
formulas_used: $y(x) = \frac{P x^3}{6 E I} - \frac{P a x^2}{2 E I}$

topic.name: Deflection of Beams (Euler-Bernoulli beam theory)
topic.syllabus_ref: Structures -> Bending of beams, deflection by integration and standard formulas

concepts.name: Cantilever beam deflection under point load
Second moment of area of rectangular section
Elastic curve differential equation $E I y'' = M(x)$

essential: Euler-Bernoulli beam theory and relation $E I y'' = M(x)$
Calculation of second moment of area for simple sections
Understanding of cantilever boundary conditions (zero deflection and slope at fixed end)
helpful: Ability to sketch bending moment diagrams
Familiarity with standard beam deflection formulas for quick checks

Main Concept: requires: Section properties (second moment of area)
enables: Analysis of more complex beam loadings using superposition
enables: Structural sizing of aircraft components for stiffness requirements

difficulty_factors: Requires recalling or deriving deflection expression for a cantilever with an off-tip point load
Careful handling of units (GPa, mm vs m) is needed to get answer in mm

textbook_references.author: Timoshenko and Gere
textbook_references.text_snippet: Derives the elastic curve for cantilever beams under various point load positions using the differential equation $E I y'' = M(x)$.

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.text_snippet: Applies beam theory to aircraft structural members, including cantilevers with point loads at arbitrary positions.

textbook_references.author: Beer and Johnston
textbook_references.text_snippet: Lists standard deflection formulas for cantilever and simply supported beams under point and distributed loads.

video_references.book_reference: Beer and Johnston, Mechanics of Materials
video_references.topic_covered: Standard deflection formulas for cantilever and simply supported beams
Deflection of cantilever beam and equivalent stiffness

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Set up bending moment function -> Use EI y'' = M(x) -> Integrate with boundary and continuity conditions -> Evaluate deflection at free end -> Substitute numerical values
key_insights: For a point load not at the free end, the bending moment is piecewise; only the segment beyond the load carries moment.
Using the general expression $y(L) = P L^3/(12 E I)$ for a mid-span load on a cantilever is much faster once derived.
Checking dimensions (N·m^3 / (Pa·m^4) = m) helps verify algebra.

formulas_principles.name: Differential equation of elastic curve
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to slender beams under small deflections with linear elastic material behavior
formulas_principles.relevance: Core relation connecting bending moment to curvature and hence deflection

formulas_principles.name: Second moment of area of rectangle about neutral axis
formulas_principles.conditions: Rectangle of width b and depth h, bending about axis through centroid parallel to width
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute flexural rigidity E I of the beam

formulas_principles.name: Bending moment due to point load at distance a on cantilever
formulas_principles.conditions: Region of beam where x \ge a, measured from fixed end
formulas_principles.relevance: Provides the loading term in the elastic curve equation

formulas_principles.name: Tip deflection of cantilever with mid-span point load
formulas_principles.conditions: Point load applied at a = L/2 from fixed end, small deflection theory
formulas_principles.relevance: Directly yields the required free-end deflection for this problem

industry_examples: Deflection analysis of aircraft wing attachments where concentrated loads from engines or stores act at intermediate points along a cantilevered wing box.
Design of sensor booms or antenna masts on satellites and aircraft, where equipment weight is attached away from the base.
specific_systems: Wing-mounted stores on fighter aircraft pylons modeled as cantilever beams with loads at specific stations.
Helicopter tail booms treated as cantilevers with concentrated loads from tail rotor gearboxes.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Accurate prediction of beam deflections ensures that structural components meet stiffness and clearance requirements, preventing excessive deformation that could cause control issues, fatigue, or interference with other parts.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the formula for a cantilever with a point load at the free end ($y = P L^3 / (3 E I)$) instead of deriving the expression for a load at mid-span.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They memorize a few standard formulas and try to apply them blindly without checking load position.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always sketch the bending moment diagram and confirm where the load is applied before selecting a formula.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives a deflection four times larger than the correct value, leading to a wrong numerical answer.

common_mistakes.mistake: Incorrect calculation of second moment of area, e.g., using $I = b^3 h / 12$ or forgetting the division by 12.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusion between bending about different axes and rushing through algebra.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Write the formula symbolically first and check dimensions: I should have units of m^4.
common_mistakes.consequence: Results in deflection off by a factor of 10–12, moving the answer outside the accepted range.

common_mistakes.mistake: Mixing units by keeping E in GPa and lengths in mm without consistent conversion.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Trying to directly get answer in mm without a clear unit plan.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Perform all calculations in SI base units (N, m, Pa) and convert to mm only in the final step.
common_mistakes.consequence: Can produce answers off by factors of 10^3 or 10^6.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming zero bending moment in the region beyond the load (towards the free end) instead of recognizing that the segment between load and fixed end carries the moment.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Misinterpretation of internal forces and free-body diagrams.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Draw the free-body of a cut section and remember that internal moment balances external loads to the right of the cut.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to M(x) = 0 and hence zero deflection, which is clearly unphysical.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: For a rectangular section, think "B-HHH over 12" (b × h^3 / 12).
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Second moment of area of a rectangle about its centroidal axis
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever you need I for rectangular or square beam sections.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Cantilever tip load: 3 in the denominator; mid-span load: 12 in the denominator.
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Difference between deflection formulas for tip load and mid-span load on a cantilever
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Helps recall that mid-span load causes smaller deflection than same load at the tip.

flashcards.front: What is the differential equation relating bending moment M(x) and deflection y(x) in Euler-Bernoulli beam theory?
Give the second moment of area I of a rectangle of width b and depth h about its centroidal axis parallel to width.
A cantilever of length L has a point load P at mid-span (L/2). Write the free-end deflection in terms of P, L, E, and I.
Why can you NOT use $y = P L^3 / (3 E I)$ for a cantilever with a load at L/2?
flashcards.back: Because that formula is only for a point load at the free end. When the load is at L/2, the bending moment distribution and integration constants change, giving $y(L) = P L^3 / (12 E I)$.

flashcards.front: What boundary conditions apply at the fixed end of a cantilever in small-deflection theory?

real_world_context.application: Deflection of aircraft wing roots and tail booms under concentrated equipment loads.
real_world_context.industry_example: An avionics box mounted halfway along a cantilevered sensor boom; engineers must ensure the tip deflection stays within a few millimeters to maintain sensor pointing accuracy.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Excessive deflection can misalign sensors, cause aeroelastic issues, or lead to fatigue cracking due to unexpected stress distributions.

real_world_context.application: Design of overhanging crane beams and robotic arms.
real_world_context.industry_example: A robotic arm with a gripper mounted mid-way must limit end deflection to maintain precise positioning during assembly operations.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Poor stiffness prediction leads to positioning errors, collisions, or reduced product quality.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize this as a standard beam-deflection problem: quickly compute I, recall or derive the formula for mid-span load on a cantilever, plug in numbers, and convert to mm.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure of the exact coefficient, compare with the tip-load case (P L^3 / 3 E I). Since the load is closer to the fixed end, expect a smaller deflection; a coefficient around 1/12 is reasonable.
exam_strategy.time_management: Limit yourself to about 2–3 minutes. If the integration seems long, use known standard formulas or dimensional checks to speed up.

search_keywords: cantilever beam deflection point load at distance a
Euler-Bernoulli beam equation EI y'' = M(x)
second moment of area square cross section
GATE AE structures beam deflection problems
Beer Johnston deflection of beams integration method

alternative_methods.name: Superposition using equivalent loads
alternative_methods.description: Model the load at mid-span as a combination of simpler load cases (e.g., treat the beam as two segments or use tabulated solutions) and superpose their deflections to obtain the free-end deflection.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Faster if you memorize standard cases; reduces integration work. Cons: Requires remembering more formulas and may be confusing for non-standard load positions.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful in exams when standard deflection tables are memorized and time is short.

alternative_methods.name: Castigliano's Theorem (strain energy method)
alternative_methods.description: Compute the strain energy in the beam due to bending, then differentiate the energy with respect to the applied load to obtain the deflection at the load point, and use compatibility to find tip deflection.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Systematic and extends well to statically indeterminate structures. Cons: More algebraic work than direct integration for this simple determinate case.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Better for complex loadings or indeterminate beams where direct integration is cumbersome.

connections_to_other_subjects.Vibrations: The same flexural rigidity E I and static deflection formulas are used to compute equivalent stiffness of beams in vibration problems, which then determine natural frequencies.
connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Wing and tail deflections affect aerodynamic center positions and control effectiveness, linking structural flexibility to stability and control.
connections_to_other_subjects.Finite Element Methods: Beam deflection theory underpins 1D beam elements used in FEM codes for structural analysis.
connections_to_other_subjects.Materials Science: Young's modulus E, a material property, directly influences stiffness and deflection, connecting microstructure to structural performance.

deeper_dive_topics: Timoshenko beam theory including shear deformation and rotary inertia
Nonlinear large-deflection beam behavior beyond small deformation theory
Aeroelasticity and coupling between aerodynamic loads and beam deflection
Optimization of beam cross-sections for stiffness-to-weight ratio in aerospace structures

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Bending of beams, shear force and bending moment, deflection of beams
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent representative problem testing core beam deflection skills with direct relevance to aerospace structural design.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided general beam deflection formulas and stiffness concepts for cantilever beams, which are related but not specific to a mid-span point load. Core solution relied on standard Euler-Bernoulli theory from internal knowledge, with RAG mainly supporting background understanding and formula checks.

future_questions_potential: Ask for maximum bending stress in the same cantilever under the mid-span load and compare with allowable stress.
Modify the problem to include a uniformly distributed load in addition to the point load and ask for combined deflection.
Extend to find the first natural frequency of transverse vibration using the equivalent stiffness from static deflection.
Consider a hollow rectangular or I-section instead of solid square and ask students to compute both I and deflection.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: Consider a cantilever beam having length L=1 m, square cross-section (width = depth = 0.01 m) and Young's modulus 50 GPa. The beam is subjected to a transverse load P = 1 N at the mid-span (L/2) at the center of the cross-section. Under the small deformation theory, the transverse deflection of the beam (in mm) at its free-end is
